com.rds_software.customers.menarini.projects.odp.backend

Class OdpUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rds_software.customers.menarini.projects.odp.backend.OdpUtils

  • public class OdpUtils
extends Object
    Utility class providing business logic validation for ODP (Ordine di Pagamento) operations.

    This class centralizes permission checking and validation logic for ODP editing and approval operations, ensuring consistency across both frontend (UI) and backend (service) layers.

    Key Validation Rules:

    • Edit Operations: Only owners can edit ODPs in DRAFT or TEMPLATE states
    • Approval Operations: Only the assigned approver with the correct role can approve/reject ODPs in WAITING_AUTH_* states
    Author:
    Claude Code
    See Also:
    OdpStateType, RoleType

    • Method Detail

      • isCanBeEdited

        public static boolean isCanBeEdited(Odp odp,
                                    OdpUser user)
        Determines whether a specific user can edit the given ODP.

        An ODP can be edited only if ALL of the following conditions are met:

        1. The ODP is in a state that allows editing (DRAFT or TEMPLATE)
        2. The user has a role with edit permissions (PROPOSER role)
        3. The user is the owner of the ODP

        This method is used by both the frontend security manager to enable/disable UI controls and by the backend service to enforce business rules.

        Parameters:
        odp - the ODP to check for edit permissions
        user - the user attempting to edit the ODP
        Returns:
        true if the user can edit the ODP, false otherwise
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the ODP or required fields (state, owner) are null
        See Also:
        OdpStateType.isOdpCanBeEdited(), RoleType.canEdit()

      • isCanBeApproved

        public static boolean isCanBeApproved(Odp odp,
                                      OdpUser user)
        Determines whether a specific user can approve or reject the given ODP.

        An ODP can be approved/rejected only if ALL of the following conditions are met:

        1. The ODP is in a state that allows approval (WAITING_AUTH_SIGNER_1, WAITING_AUTH_SIGNER_2, or WAITING_AUTH_PAYER)
        2. The user has a role with approval permissions (SIGNER_1, SIGNER_2, or PAYER)
        3. The user is the current assignee for this approval step
        4. The user's role matches the expected role for the current ODP state:
          • WAITING_AUTH_SIGNER_1 requires SIGNER_1 role
          • WAITING_AUTH_SIGNER_2 requires SIGNER_2 role
          • WAITING_AUTH_PAYER requires PAYER role

        The assignee field must be explicitly set before approval operations to designate which specific user should approve the current step. This prevents users from approving steps not assigned to them, even if they have the correct role.

        This method is used by both the frontend security manager to enable/disable approval/rejection buttons and by the backend service to enforce authorization rules.

        Parameters:
        odp - the ODP to check for approval permissions
        user - the user attempting to approve or reject the ODP
        Returns:
        true if the user can approve/reject the ODP, false otherwise
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the ODP or required fields (state, assignee) are null
        See Also:
        OdpStateType.isOdpCanBeApproved(), RoleType.canApprove()

      • isOdpEligibleForApproval

        public static boolean isOdpEligibleForApproval(Odp odp,
                                               OdpUser user)
        Determines whether a specific user can make the given ODP eligible for approval.

        An ODP can be made eligible for approval (i.e., submitted for the approval workflow) only if ALL of the following conditions are met:

        1. The ODP is in a state that allows it to be made eligible for approval
        2. The user has the PROPOSER role (the role that can submit ODPs for approval)
        3. The user is the owner of the ODP

        This method is typically used to determine if the user can submit their ODP to begin the approval workflow, transitioning it from DRAFT state to the first approval state (WAITING_AUTH_SIGNER_1).

        Parameters:
        odp - the ODP to check for approval eligibility submission permissions
        user - the user attempting to make the ODP eligible for approval
        Returns:
        true if the user can make the ODP eligible for approval, false otherwise
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the ODP or required fields (state, owner) are null
        See Also:
        OdpStateType.isOdpEligibleForApproval(), RoleType.PROPOSER

      • getWaitingStateForRole

        public static OdpStateType getWaitingStateForRole(RoleType role)
        Converts an approval role to its corresponding waiting state in the ODP approval workflow.

        This method provides a centralized mapping between approval roles and their associated ODP states, ensuring consistency across the approval workflow. The mapping reflects the sequential approval process:

        • SIGNER_1 role â†’ WAITING_AUTH_SIGNER_1 state
        • SIGNER_2 role â†’ WAITING_AUTH_SIGNER_2 state
        • PAYER role â†’ WAITING_AUTH_PAYER state

        This mapping is used by the approval workflow to determine the next state when assigning an ODP to a specific approver. The inverse mapping (state â†’ required role) is enforced by the isCanBeApproved(Odp, OdpUser) method.

        Parameters:
        role - the approval role to convert to a waiting state
        Returns:
        the corresponding ODP waiting state for the given role
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the role is not an approval role (e.g., PROPOSER)
        See Also:
        isCanBeApproved(Odp, OdpUser), RoleType, OdpStateType
